paragraphs.content: The present perfect (‘passato prossimo’) is one of the two most used past tenses of the indicative in Italian (the other is the imperfect (‘imperfetto’)). The present perfect is often used like the English present perfect (e.g. ‘I have seen it’, ‘She has gone home’) to state that an action has happened in the past, but that its effects are still lasting in the present. However, in Northern Italy and in the language of the media, it is also equivalent to the English simple past (e.g. ‘I saw it’, ‘She went home’), referring to actions which happened in a more distant past and have no immediate consequences in the present. Indeed, it more often corresponds to the English simple past than to the English present perfect. In other words, in Italian, the difference between present perfect (‘passato prossimo’) and simple past (‘passato remoto’) is not always marked, and it is always possible to use the former:

rows: L’estate scorsa siamo andati in vacanza sul lago di Garda.
Last summer we went to Lake Garda for our/a holiday.
L’anno scorso, mi hanno regalato una mountain bike.
Last year, they gave me a mountain bike.

paragraphs.content: The present perfect is a compound tense and is formed, as in English, with the present tense of the auxiliary verb followed by the past participle of the verb:

rows: I saw/have seen a lovely film.
Did they go/Have they gone to the swimming pool?

paragraphs.content: As the examples confirm, the ‘passato prossimo’ may correspond to either the simple past or the present perfect in English. But there are also other differences between the Italian and English structures: there is only one auxiliary verb in English (‘to have’), but in Italian there is a choice of two, avere and essere; when essere is used, the past participle has to agree in gender and number with the subject; finally, whether to use avere or essere is not usually a free choice. We will look at all these differences in detail, but first we need to look at the forms of the Italian past participle.
The regular forms of the past participle are obtained by changing the ending of the infinitive as follows:
* Verbs ending in -cere (or -scere) keep the ‘soft’ sound of c (or sc) and therefore add an i before the -uto ending (-iuto).
In Italian, as in most languages, many verbs have an irregular past participle, which is best learned by heart and with use. Here is a list of the most frequently used:
* Stato is also the past participle of stare. ** The regular forms perduto and veduto are rarely used.

The present perfect in Italian is formed with the present indicative of avere or essere (auxiliary verbs) followed by the past participle of the verb. Here are two examples, one using avere and the other essere:

As can be seen, when the present perfect is formed with avere the past participle does not change; but when the present perfect is formed with essere the past participle behaves like an adjective, agreeing in gender and number with the subject of the verb. Here are some examples:

rows: Did you buy/Have you bought the bread?
Did you book/Have you booked, Mr Ferro?
Fabia e Silvia sono rimaste a casa. [fp]
Fabia and Silvia (have) stayed at home.
I went/I’ve been to the cinema. [the speaker is female]
We (have) arrived late. [the speakers are males or a mixed group]
Signor Poli, Lei quando è arrivato?* [ms]
When did you arrive, Mr Poli?
Signora Poli, Lei quando è arrivata?* [fs]
When did you arrive, Mrs Poli?

paragraphs.content: * When the polite form is used and the auxiliary is essere, the past participle agrees with the gender of the person being spoken to, not with Lei.

sections.title: Present perfect of avere and essere

paragraphs.content: Avere forms the present perfect with the auxiliary avere:
Essere forms the present perfect with the auxiliary essere:

rows: La settimana scorsa abbiamo avuto ospiti.
Des was a student of mine.

paragraphs.content: Like the present, the present perfect of essere can be used with the pronoun ci (see Unit 4): c’è stato/stata (there was/has been), ci sono stati/state (there were/have been):

rows: There were/have been too many accidents.

paragraphs.content: Deciding whether to use essere or avere can be a bit of a problem. The only firm rules are those governing transitive verbs (i.e. verbs which can have a direct object) and reflexive verbs (see Unit 20). Transitive verbs always use avere; reflexive verbs always use essere. As for intransitive verbs, some use avere and others essere. In general, it can be said that verbs of movement (such as andare (to go), venire (to come), partire (to leave), uscire (to go out), entrare (to go in/come in)) or nonmovement (such as rimanere (to remain), restare (to stay/remain)), and verbs of state (such as essere, diventare (to become), cambiare (to change), crescere (to grow)) use the auxiliary essere. However, this is not a hard and fast rule: there are intransitive verbs which take avere.

rows: Ho conosciuto i genitori di Gianni. [transitive]
Did you send/Have you sent your postcards?
Ieri sera siamo andati a un concerto rock. [intransitive]
Last night we went to a rock concert.
Domenica scorsa siamo rimasti a casa. [intransitive]
Last Sunday we stayed at home.

paragraphs.content: To help in choosing the right auxiliary, here is a list of common verbs which form the present perfect with essere:

rows: it was/has been enough they were/have been enough
it cost/has cost they cost/have cost
I went/have gone in/I entered/have entered
it pleased/has pleased they pleased/have pleased
it happened/has happened they happened/have happened

paragraphs.content: * These verbs are normally only used in the third person singular and plural:

rows: How much did that bicycle cost?
La bici è costata più di 900 euro.
Le è piaciuto il film, Signora?
Did you like the film(, Madam)?
Da allora sono successe molte cose.*
Since then many things have happened/After that many things happened.

paragraphs.content: * Note that succedere is an impersonal verb: something or things can happen, but succedere cannot be used like the English ‘I happened to be in Rome’ etc.
The negative is formed by putting non before the auxiliary:

rows: Ieri non sono andato a scuola.
I didn’t go to school yesterday.
Lisa non è riuscita a finire quel lavoro.
Lisa didn’t manage/hasn’t managed to finish that job.
Didn’t you phone/Haven’t you phoned Fabia?

paragraphs.content: The adverbs ancora (again), mai (ever), più (more/again) and già (already) are normally placed between the auxiliary and the verb (e.g. Ho già risposto (I’ve already replied)). When they are used in the negative – non . . . ancora (not . . . yet), non . . . mai (never), non . . . più (not . . . any more/not . . . again/no . . . longer) (see also Unit 6, paragraph 2) – non is placed before the auxiliary:

rows: Did you go/Have you been to the library again?
Siete mai stati su un ghiacciaio?
Have you ever been on a glacier?
Hai più visto i tuoi amici?
Have you (ever) seen your friends again?
Non abbiamo ancora preso il biglietto.
We haven’t bought the ticket yet.
Paola non è mai stata a Venezia.
Paola has never been to Venice.

paragraphs.content: The present perfect of dovere, potere and volere is normally formed with the auxiliary avere, but when they are followed by a verb which forms the present perfect with essere, they may take essere as well; if essere is used, the past participle of the verb agrees with the subject:

rows: I nostri amici hanno dovuto partire.
I nostri amici sono dovuti partire.
Cecilia non ha potuto andare in Irlanda.
Cecilia non è potuta andare in Irlanda.
Why didn’t you want to go out?
Why didn’t you want to go out?

paragraphs.content: Remember that it is never wrong to use avere:

rows: Maria ha dovuto rimanere a casa.
Maria (has) had to stay at home.
Elena couldn’t/hasn’t been able to phone.
Elena e Sergio non hanno potuto entrare.
Elena and Sergio couldn’t/haven’t been able to get in.

examples: Le mie amiche sono uscit—: uscite

items.question: Francesca e Filippo sono restat— a casa.
Giulia e Susanna non sono uscit— ieri sera.
I miei amici sono arrivat— domenica scorsa.
Quando Fabia è entrat— , ha visto gli amici.
Pierluigi non è riuscit— a finire il lavoro.

exercises.title: Exercise 2
exercises.instruction: Supply the present perfect of the verb in brackets.

items.question: Ieri sera (noi andare) a un concerto.
(io dovere) studiare molto per questo esame.
(noi giocare) a pallone tutto il pomeriggio.

exercises.title: Exercise 3
exercises.instruction: Supply the present perfect of the verb in brackets.

items.question: Non (noi riuscire) a finire in tempo.
Ugo e Marina non (venire) a cena da noi.
Il treno (partire) con mezz’ora di ritardo.
I haven’t finished reading the paper yet.
items.answer: Non ho ancora finito di leggere il giornale.

items.question: Stefano’s never been to Rome.
items.answer: Stefano non è mai stato a Roma.

items.question: I didn’t see Roberto again after the party.
items.answer: Non ho più visto Roberto dopo la festa.

items.question: Have you [pl.] already paid the bill?
Giulia hasn’t started working yet.
items.answer: Giulia non ha ancora cominciato a lavorare.

items.question: Carlo couldn’t work any more.
items.answer: Carlo non ha più potuto lavorare.

items.question: I’ve never met her parents.
items.answer: Non ho mai conosciuto i suoi genitori.

items.question: Have you [sing.] written the letters already?
I’ve never seen that film.
items.answer: Non ho mai visto quel film.
